bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Frederick R. Russell, August 10, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302047]

div1.p: Hanson writes Russell about his trip along the Magdalena River in Colombia in preparation for a clean up campaign to try and halt the spread of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Frederick R. Russell, August 10, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302047]
div1.opener:
(1) Colombia
COPY
Bogota, Colombia
August 10, 1923.
Col. F. F. Russell, General Director,
International Health Board,
New York City.
My dear Col. Russell:
div1.p:
We arrived in Bogota on the 7th after a hot trip up the river.
Although we were eight days making the trip from Barranquilla to this
place they tell us that we made a very quick trip for this time of the year.
This feature of the time consumed in moving from place to place, while it
may (theoretically) impede the progress of the fever, hampers us a great
deal in the distribution and shifting of our forces to meet emergencies which
may come up. It also makes it very difficult to keep up the supervision of
the work by supervising inspectors. Added to this is the surprisingly high
cost of everything which I have investigated so far. A campaign here such
as I conducted in Peru would cost at least twice what it cost there.

While it is somewhat premature to predict what should be done and
to what points the prophylactic work ought to be extended, I am very much
inclined to think that Cartagena, the Port of Colombia and Barranquilla
should be included and thoroughly cleaned up. I gained this impression as
I came up the Magdelena and saw the large number of small villages along the
coast, which can easily serve as relaying points for the conduction of the
fever down to the coast. I can see nothing to prevent this from happening.
The peones travel from point to point, and it will be simply a matter of
luck if the fever is not carried down the river in this manner. The land
and ship quarantine of which you have been informed is a myth, and for my
part I do not place the least bit of reliance in these efforts, or rather
I should say supposed efforts.

When we came up we went ashore at Barrnca Bermeja, where we were
told by both the Physician of the Tropical Oil and a Colombian Physician from
Bucaramanga that there was no yellow fever there, and yet the Garcia family
who were fellow passengers were told by relatives of theirs in the native
village that there had been quite a few cases of “pernicious fevers” with
several deaths. On our return we will endeavor to investigate the nature of
these fevers.

Yesterday we called at the laboratory of Samper & Martinez and saw
some of their cultures of leptospira, and with the exception of the fact that
the organisms did not show the pronounced activity of those which Noguchi
has, I would be unable to say that they are not Leptospira icteriodes. Mor-
phologically they appeared the same. They had one guinea pig which looked
very typical.

I am remaining here until we have a full understanding about the
management of the campaign and have secured the necessary resolutions
authorizing us to take up the work in any place where it may seem advisable
to do so.

Today we attended the services in memory of Mr. Harding, at the
American Legation.
